rename.from: [ENH] Adding offset argument to transformers that do not support negative values
rename.to: [ENH] Adding `offset` argument to transformers that do not support negative values

body:
A valid alternative would be to create an offset transformer and use it in a pipeline with the other ones. 
Not sure what's best but makes sense to have a little debate on it.
you could use a `MinMaxScaler` before those transformers that can not deal with <0 or <=0 values, would be more accurate I guess.

Lots of options here, but it would be most convenient for users to have the `offset` argument and set it to `auto` as done in `ExponentTransformer`. That way users do not have to do anything additional. 

Of course, they could use the other alternatives that have been mentioned but it is more inconvenient to add additional wrappers. Just my 2 cents on this.

I feel it would be better (can skip refactoring other transformers which are supporting negative values eg: exponential) to add an `offset` argument to transformers that are not supporting negative values. And also, the log transformation of values between 0 and 1 (obtained from MinMax Scaler of default `feature_range=(0, 1)`) would give negative values that again need to be handled, I suppose. MinMax Scaler with `feature_range=(1, variable)` also seems to be a nice alternative to me. Please let me know your view, I am happy to know.

Hm, I tend to agree with @aiwalter - why not just use a `MinMaxScaler` as a pipeline element?
Adding `offset` to a million transformers seems like multiplication and a violation of the DRY principle.

other option I can think of is having an `OffsetTransformer` compostion similar to the `OptionalPassthrough`. The `OffsetTransformer` would hold the functionality to offset and possibly have params `offset: bool = True` and `value: float/int = 0`
.
So when you want to offset a transformer, you could do `OffsetTransformer(BoxCoxTransformer())`

>Adding offset to a million transformers seems like multiplication and a violation of the DRY principle.

@fkiraly Maybe having an `OffsetMixin` class would address this?

> other option I can think of is having an `OffsetTransformer` compostion similar to the `OptionalPassthrough`. The `OffsetTransformer` would hold the functionality to offset and possibly have params `offset: bool = True` and `value: float/int = 0`
> .
> So when you want to offset a transformer, you could do `OffsetTransformer(BoxCoxTransformer())`

Why is this better than just `BoxCoxTransformer()` with default argument `offset = "auto"`? It seems much more simpler from a users perspective so instead of tuning like `transformer__limits` to access pipeline params, one would only have to do `limits`. Plus less overhead when writing out the code for the user as well.

Maybe having both "offset" argument with a MixinClass and an `OffsetTransformer` might also be an option if there is no easy conclusion.

Yes I actually also dont prefer the composition. If we add it anyhow as a param we should also deprecate the `OptionalPassthrough` and have it in the same way as offset added to the transformers as it is also a functionality that we want to enable for all transformers. We could also add `offset` and `passthrough` params to the base class and give it to `super().__init__(offset, passthrough)`. The logic to passthrough/offset could be implemented in `fit()` and `transform()`, so we would only have to update `super` and the docstring for all transformers.

> @fkiraly Maybe having an OffsetMixin class would address this?

That wouldn't automatically add the offset to the parameters, so I think it wouldn't work.
It would have to be at least a decorator, and that just invites trouble...

> Why is this better than just BoxCoxTransformer() with default argument offset = "auto"? It seems much more simpler from a users perspective

Hm, I disagree - the user familiar with the Box-Cox transform willl probably expect the transformer to produce nan or to break if there are negative values for certain exponents. The "offsetting" logic will come as a surprise, and will conceptually not be part of someone's mental model of the Box-Cox transform!

User surprise and user frustrationn is the result - and in hindsight, I think that the "offset" logic does *not* really belong in the ` BoxCoxTransformer` either.

@ngupta23, what would be wrong about writing sth like

`OffsetNegatives() * BoxCoxTransformer()`, as @aiwalter proposes?

That makes it much clearer what is happening - design principle being, specification should map as closely as possible on the mental model.

> Yes I actually also dont prefer the composition. If we add it anyhow as a param we should also deprecate the `OptionalPassthrough` and have it in the same way as offset added to the transformers as it is also a functionality that we want to enable for all transformers.

Ok, I think that is a bad idea, @aiwalter. This will lead to monstrosities since all transformers now are going to contain composition with two other transformers. And why not add all the parameters of the min/max scaler too? That direction I really do not like. "Simple is better than complex."

And it's also not DRY! We need to update "docstrings for all the transformers", as you say, and "only" the init (and what else?), too.
So, I liked your first suggestion much better than the second, @aiwalter 😄

> User surprise and user frustrationn is the result - and in hindsight, I think that the "offset" logic does not really belong in the BoxCoxTransformer either.

@fkiraly - Did you mean does not belong in the `ExponentTransformer`? If so is it going to be removed?

> @ngupta23, what would be wrong about writing sth like
OffsetNegatives() * BoxCoxTransformer(), as @aiwalter proposes?

I am not familiar with this syntax. Are you referring to a nested pipeline like this?

```python
OffsetNegatives(BoxCoxTransformer())
```
